29.50.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
our stars are finding out about camouflage

35.70.text:
in most unusual ways. Jonny Crockett is making
tools out of bits of old wood. But first the

43.87.text:
pigeons are on the maize. Be prepared to be
amazed by George Digweed.

54.87.text:
It's our Christmas catch-up with George - who
is looking particularly festive if not fashion

61.43.text:
To be honest with you I don't care what it
looks like as long as my head is warm.

69.27.text:
On a crisp December afternoon he's taking
time out from shooting to do some… shooting.

75.03.text:
At this time of year the 20 times world champion
is flat out looking after his sporting days,

81.13.text:
but for George this really is R&R with a bit
of pest control thrown in.

85.53.text:
It is always nice to have a break and get
out and have a shot when the season is on

94.26.text:
- do you know what I mean. It is really hard
work for us at the moment, especially this

99.69.text:
year. So to get out and have a shot at the
weekend is just a nice break.

104.96.text:
He's been shooting this particular spot on
the English North Downs for a decade and it's

109.61.text: some of the most challenging sport around.

112.12.text:
When you are shooting pigeons like this. This
is where your technique has to be absolutely

118.09.text:
sound because you will get a good pigeon come
in fairly close to you, come up wind and swing

124.40.text:
round over the top at 15 or 20 yards and then
the next pigeon you shoot at will be 75 yards.

131.46.text:
So your technique has to be sound and you
have to be confident of being able to judge

135.94.text:
your distance and judge your lines. It is
not about a big bag today, it is about having

140.57.text:
some fantastic shooting and we should get
that.

144.44.text:
George doesn't have any decoys out - just
a magnet to his left at about 65 yards. He

151.12.text:
is tucked in the shadow of the wood behind
us which is, again, about 60 yards away. It's

157.07.text:
worth mentioning these distances to get a
sense of perspective. 90% of the birds George

162.49.text:
is shooting today are more than 60 yards away
with some nearing 100. And you know when George

169.94.text:
Ooh that was a beauty. Ooh what a beauty,
ooh what a pigeon. Ooh......look at that.

196.35.text:
Absolutely. No point in doing it if you can't
enjoy it.

199.87.text:
Now it cannot be denied that 2012 has been
a fantastic year for British sporting achievement

206.57.text:
and with the BBC's sports personality of the
year coming up surely a man who has been world

212.09.text:
champion so many times in his chosen discipline
would get some sort of recognition - or may

218.16.text:
I can't imagine why they would ask me this
year. They haven't asked me many other years.

223.73.text:
That was a nice one. They haven't asked me
many other years. I went 3 times and the last

230.03.text:
time I went was in Birmingham and they put
me up in the ceiling and it was just a waste

239.19.text:
of time. I hope Pete Wilson goes and gets
some good coverage. I hope he gets invited

246.84.text:
to it and I hope they interview him and I
hope he comes across well, because he has

252.10.text: got an ideal opportunity to promote the sport.

254.33.text:
The one thing Pete didn't have to worry about
during the games was a cold cartridge - George

259.70.text:
will now explain why it is important to look
after your shells during the winter months...

264.53.text:
Yes, if you look up the barrels there, just
up in to the sky you can see the residue there

269.13.text:
left up in there which is where the cartridges
have been kept in damp conditions. The powder

277.55.text:
has got a little damp so they burn a bit slower.
It doesn't really affect the performance hugely,

283.59.text: but obviously it is not ideal.

293.97.text:
Now these are some I have had on the radiator
and you can see now that there is no residue

307.42.text:
George warned us we'd see lots of birds today
and he has not disappointed. His friend Will

312.81.text:
described today's shooting as like the best
presented highest pheasant drive and it lasts

318.46.text:
for four hours. He's not wrong. Many people
would find shooting at these ranges too extreme

325.52.text: but George makes it look easy.

329.40.text:
At this time of year George gets a lot of
invites to shoots all over the country as

333.40.text:
well as looking after his own. One thing that
he has noticed is an upsetting trend that

338.52.text:
some guns are not using their second shot
to ensure the bird is dead.

342.74.text:
You see people that shoot in a flush of pheasants
they hit the first one and then go straight

348.55.text:
on to another bird. When the first one is
not dead and they should finish that bird

353.64.text:
off. If I am shooting I will always finish
off. If I have hit a bird I will always finish

359.73.text: it off rather than go to another bird.

361.63.text:
With the sun dropping fast George starts to
tidy up. It's going to take a while..

366.64.text:
We have done a good job here today killing
pigeons that are going out to the rape. It

371.53.text:
has been quite a difficult day I would say,
but no it has been a very good sporting day

380.30.text:
and when they come like that there is no finer
bird in the world.

384.72.text:
With three other guns keeping the birds moving,
the group have shot slightly more than George

389.26.text:
predicted: an impressive 813. George shot
140 once again proving he is king of the hill.

397.30.text:
From birds in the air to a bird in a suit,
it is David on the Fieldsports Channel News

413.28.text:
A British animal rights organisation plans
a day of action on 15 December 2012. Its claims

420.38.text:
its activists - all 2 of them - will be leafleting
outside the British newsagent WHSmith across

425.64.text:
the UK, to protest against the sale of shooting
magazines to young people. WHSmith recently

431.54.text:
went back on a policy to age-restrict shooting
magazines. You can order your own leaflets

436.15.text:
and postcards via the Animal Aid website www.animalaid.org.uk
- they make great loft insulation.

445.33.text:
Bear hunting with dogs is to be banned in
the American state of California. Some 1,700

450.92.text:
black bears out of a population of up to 39,000
are shot in California each year. Almost half

457.14.text:
are with the help of hounds. Hunters are required
by law to eat the meat. But hunters who trace

462.63.text:
their lineage back to George Washington, Daniel
Boone and Theodore Roosevelt will only be

467.27.text:
allowed to use guns, not hounds, from 1st
January 2013.

472.58.text:
Gun crime across Scotland fell by 20% between
2010 and 2011, according to the latest figures.

479.64.text:
The Scottish Government says there were five
murders involving guns and 11 attempted murders.

484.85.text:
Scotland faces a ban on airguns. However,
the figures show that just 195 out of an estimated

490.98.text:
half a million airguns in circulation in Scotland
were used in crimes in 2011.

497.11.text:
Sporting Shooter magazine has launched a new
website. As well as news and reviews there

501.61.text:
are also video contents starring the likes
of Andy Crow, Mark Gilchrist and Roy Lupton.

506.30.text:
Other UK magazines are also seeing the benefit
of promoting shooting and field sports through

511.68.text:
Youtube. Countryman's weekly magazine is now
putting our films on its face book page.

516.77.text:
And finally, it's the third yellowfin tuna
record we have reported this year. A California

523.10.text:
man reeled in a 445lb tuna but it won't go
in to the books because someone else touched

528.51.text:
the fishing rod. Boat captain Justin Fleck
said he helped angler John Petruescu negotiate

533.16.text: around a bow anchor for insurance reasons.

537.42.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

550.30.text:
Thank you David. Well we have all got a lot
to learn about camouflage. I have been off

554.48.text: finding out whether it is really necessary.

558.74.text: Camouflage - what works? Does it work?

561.92.text:
We've had a few instances over the year where
it didn't seem to matter what our guys were

566.87.text:
wearing. In early autumn Dom Holtam had a
wonderful wildlife moment with roe deer grazing

572.43.text:
up to within just a few yards. He did that
by standing still. Then there was Roy Lupton.

579.41.text:
Standing in the open had roebucks charging
straight towards him in the rut.

584.34.text:
So we've asked some of the gang for some guidance.
For starters, wallflower Mark Gilchrist has

590.68.text:
been a long time supporter of blending into
the background.

593.78.text:
If you are keeping still it will help you
to conceal yourself, but if you can't keep

599.02.text:
still, it doesn't matter what you are wearing
they are going to see you. You could be wearing

602.84.text:
camouflage.... one of those ridiculous, are
they called ghillie suits? with all that hair

607.63.text:
hanging off them, they will still see you
because you are moving around. They see is

612.21.text:
movement. Most birds I think are colour blind
or they have got poor colour vision and what

617.11.text:
they see is movement. Also if you wait until
the pigeons are just about settling and they

623.05.text:
are flying alright. If you get up doesn't
matter what you are wearing, they can't see

625.89.text:
you, because they are focused on not hitting
the ground.

630.51.text:
We've asked Mark to take camo to a new level.
Is it the emperor's new clothes?

635.57.text:
Get on, get on. That is what I love about
Labradors over girlfriends, because girlfriend

644.53.text:
now would just go mental. Have you ever turned
up at a dinner party dressed like this? They

649.25.text:
don't like it, but Dawn just thinks the whole
thing is a lot more fun.

653.32.text:
If what you say is true, you should be able
to shoot some pigeons like that.

656.92.text:
Yes, no problem at all. My modelling career
never really took off. I am not sure I am

665.00.text:
going to swing through properly. I have really
worn things that....it is not really my size

672.38.text: is it? I am going to keep it though.

676.05.text: I certainly don't want it back.

676.61.text: I am quite offended by that actually.

681.04.text:
We'll come back to Mark later and see how
he's getting on.

685.79.text:
Broadly it comes down to what birds and animals
can actually see. Do the colours matter or

694.17.text:
Andy Crow has also been known to wear camo
but today he's going to try and shoot a few

698.99.text:
crows whilst wearing a hi-vis jacket - (Our
budget couldn't stretch to two mankinis)

707.78.text:
As you can see I am wearing.....this isn't
exactly camouflage. Just had a pigeon come

715.61.text:
across the field. I stood up and shot it.
You can't get any brighter than this can you?

723.83.text:
So providing you have got a good hide, keep
still, come up when you are ready to take

729.34.text:
the shot, take the shot. Who would go pigeon
shooting in this. You wouldn't go pigeon shooting,

733.99.text:
standing in a wood walking down a hedgerow
in this, but if you have a good hide, back

739.24.text:
to field craft again, good hide, keep still,
no trouble at all.

742.51.text:
Staying low inside his expertly built hide,
and even with the sun shining directly on

747.82.text:
him, the crows and pigeons are ambushed by
Andy. He loves his camo but shooting is as

758.94.text:
Staying low also means Andy has no need to
wear a hat. Even rock gods with glossy hair

765.65.text:
can get away with it if the birds are hungry
and they stay relatively still.

770.64.text: How is it going down there.....

776.86.text:
Of course being spotted is just one way of
losing that shooting opportunity. There's

781.53.text:
also your aroma. Sensible folk stalk with
the wind in their face but you can be scent

786.73.text:
free - shampoo and washes are big business
in the United States but there are limits.

793.11.text:
Now I'm off to one of the closest things I
know to a fox: Mike Powell. I have only been

798.97.text:
at his home in Devon for five minutes when
Mike spots a rabbit. This is an ideal opportunity

804.07.text:
for the Sporting Rifle magazine expert to
show how the clothes he stands up in are as

809.40.text: good a camo as any. How close can he get?

813.53.text: How close did you get, within about 5 yards?

821.26.text:
Oh yes. But if you watch animals you can see
their reactions to what is going on and when

830.64.text:
we used to shoot foxes with shotguns you could
move out to them either in daylight or night

838.24.text:
by watching very carefully what their reactions
were and reacting to their reactions. Clearly

843.81.text:
it isn't always going to work. You are not
going to walk up to every fox, every deer

847.97.text:
it doesn't happen. But you can get away with
it quite often.

852.18.text:
So how good is modern camo? I hide a series
of camo and green jackets in a hedge. Given

858.61.text:
that Mike is part man part fox, let's walk
towards them and see which he spots first.

864.95.text:
The one I can pick out here, just about, is
the hard woods. Again that one is slightly

872.18.text:
out of context because it is in green. It
is a brown camo. But otherwise the others

877.53.text:
are still not visible. Yes, I can just about
spot the tweed. We are about 20 yards out.

886.27.text:
Yes, the battered barber I can see, but nobody
else would if they didn't know that there

895.07.text:
I would have to say.....oh dear that is difficult.
I would have to say the Rivers West.

903.43.text: For Mike, nothing beats being absolutely still.

907.54.text:
If you keep still it is almost irrelevant
what you are wearing. If you keep still long

913.89.text:
enough, they will generally relax. Not always,
but they will relax.

920.48.text:
There seems to be ever more camo patterns
on the market, but where it will all end?

951.19.text: So how is Mark getting on with the pigeons?

953.92.text:
It is a wonder when I am dressed like this
that I am ever really single.

961.95.text:
Camouflage does have it's place - and next
year we will be testing it in places where

971.19.text:
From hiding out in the woods to camping out
in the woods. Jonny Crockett from survival

975.66.text: school has got a new method for making a mallet.

987.94.text:
If you were setting up in the woods, you don't
have to bring all your tools with you. Some

992.38.text: of them you can make right here on the spot.

995.61.text:
What we are going to make is a mallet. Now
the irony of making a mallet is that ideally

1000.67.text:
you need a mallet to make a mallet. So this
is my mallet to make a mallet. It is just

1006.38.text:
a one foot length of fairly thick hazel and
I am going to make my mallet out of this.

1014.33.text:
I am going to split it in half and this end
is going to be my mallet and this end I am

1023.67.text:
going to make into four tent pegs that I am
going to use to put my tarp up later on.

1028.18.text:
I am going to measure it up, always measure
twice and cut once. So that is where I am

1033.99.text:
going to make my mark. Peg it down. You can
hear the change of noise as it gets deeper

1052.96.text:
and as it is about to fall, perfect. Now I
am going to measure this one out again. As

1061.83.text:
it happens where the bark has ripped here
that is about the same sort of size as my

1070.29.text:
So the mallet I am going to make I need to
have a handle about that long. So what I am

1080.92.text:
going to do is that I am going to turn it
around. Again I am going to put my foot on

1085.77.text:
there to give it a bit of control and I want
to cut in about a couple of centimetres, may

1093.76.text:
be a centimetre and a half, turn it around.
I keep turning it around until I have done

1111.75.text:
a full 360 and now I am going to revert back
to using my knife and the baton I showed you

1121.03.text:
So remember that is the handle, so that goes
upper most. Take the knife out of the sheath

1134.98.text:
and what we are going to do is put our knife
just on the edge up to the hilt so that when

1143.72.text:
I strike down, the cut that I am making, the
wedge I am taking out should stop when I get

1156.25.text:
down to this stop cut which I cut out with
my saw.

1158.31.text:
So I just need to make this a more ergonomic
handle now. As you can see it has lots of

1172.84.text:
ridges on it. So just cutting out to the side
which will make it a bit rounder, really.

1179.18.text:
So that it fits in my hand and becomes more
of a pleasure to use. Putting the craft back

1192.95.text:
into bush craft. There we are, lovely. But
just to give it the piece de resistance or

1210.31.text:
as Del Boy might say a piece of resistance,
I am going to bevel the top of this which

1216.29.text:
is going to stop it from splitting and from
mushrooming when I hit the pegs into the ground

1221.95.text:
a little bit later. So there we go I could
even if I wanted start to carve my name on

1227.09.text:
it and do what ever else I want. Lovely, that
is me done for the mallet.

1235.40.text:
Now from woodwork to the wider world of hunting
on Youtube it is Hunting YouTube.

1240.29.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1245.87.text:
Straight off to Poland for this clip of a
young male wild boar. Leszek Kaminski who

1250.78.text:
sent us this clip and posted it on YouTube
says the video was taken during commercial

1255.64.text:
hunt where he was a host, which is why there
is no shot. Of course, hunting cultures vary.

1260.32.text: In the UK, the host is allowed to shoot, too.

1263.32.text:
Now you may not be a bowhunter but here is
a useful film by DerekGrebner87•called TGO

1268.98.text:
HOW TO BUILD THE DEADLIEST ARROW. Anyone who
thought a cloth yard of English ash was enough

1274.02.text:
will see the error of their ways as they tangle
with a Werewolf Single Right Bevel 200-grain

1278.96.text:
Broadhead, Carbon Express Piledriver 450,
Blazer Vanes fletched right helical on a cresting

1284.94.text:
wrap, all to be twanged from a Martin Firecat
400 set at 75lb. The word ‘twanged' is my

1292.03.text:
Viewer Doug Barber sends in RMR: Bear Tagging.
It's an item about tagging hibernating bears

1297.86.text:
with Canadian comedian Rick Mercer. Now be
warned that North American humour relies on

1303.05.text:
canned laughter, but it is still a warm and
friendly piece about wildlife management that

1307.31.text: includes three cute bear cubs and no shooting.

1310.93.text:
Let's stay in Canada but with a British fishing
agent. FishSkeena offers its round-up of the

1315.77.text:
2012 season in Huge Steelhead and Trophy Chinook
Salmon flyfishing in British Columbia. The

1320.92.text: footage isn't true HD but the fish are.

1324.34.text:
Viewer Benedikt Buker kindly sent us a video
the other day. This week he sends dozens.

1329.52.text:
They will keep us going for months. Thank
you Benedikt. This one is Monster Lake Trout

1336.17.text:
The YouTube channel Horne250 has a fan in
Geoff Pickford who asks us to mention it.

1341.60.text:
Here is Autumn squirrel hunting, Horne250's
first outing on the squirrels this autumn.

1346.87.text:
If you like your rabbiting soundtrack to be
"Ooh La La" by British electronica and hip

1350.79.text:
hop band The WiseGuys, you will enjoy Rabbit
hunt .17 CZ & .22 Magnum by TheDecoyBoys.

1356.82.text:
They are shooting rabbits in silage, hay and
wheat fields. Crop damage is there for all

1362.92.text:
Sam Badham also known as SRSPower sends us
his new film Pigeon Shooting with the Whirly.

1368.16.text:
There were a lot of pigeons feeding on the
lower field when he arrived so he decided

1372.44.text:
to build the hide there. As soon as Sam was
setup they all cleared off. Still - allow

1377.54.text:
us to be pompous for a moment - good work
Sam. We like a film with a sense of story.

1382.01.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1385.26.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1392.05.text:
Well if you have been watching this on Youtube
then don't hesitate to hit the subscribe button

1396.23.text:
which I am reliably informed is now down there
or go to our shows page www.youtube.com/show/fieldsportsbritain

1405.22.text:
and click to subscribe to just this programme
and not all our films or go to our website

1409.99.text:
www.fieldsportschannel.tv where you can click
to like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter

1414.06.text:
or down on the bottom right there is the constant
contact box, pop your email address into that

1418.45.text:
and we will contact you about our programme
which is out every Wednesday at 7pm. This
